Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: An Ethnography of Collaboration in Agroforestry Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Damage to the environment continues to threaten agricultural productivity throughout the world. But policies to prevent further harm or mitigate existing damage can be difficult to develop and to enforce. Scientists have established that a major barrier to sustainable agricultural productivity is that policy makers, citizens, and scientists often have different priorities and means to achieve them. The goal of this year long, dissertation research project is to shed light on how these challenges are negotiated in practice. Taking an ethnographic approach to the real-world conduct of science and its translation into policy, the researcher will examine in fine detail the daily conduct and outcomes of collaboration among scientists from different fields, and between scientists, bureaucrats, and farmers.

The Cornell University doctoral student, Timothy McLellan, advised by Dr. Annelise Riles, will undertake the research at the Agricultural Ecology Institute, a non-governmental organization devoted to modern scientific research on the effects of traditional agricultural practices on the environment. Institute scientists from different fields collaborate with each other to carry out research; with local indigenous farmers, to advise them on the effects of their activities on the environment; and with government representatives who are charged with overseeing the development and implementation of environmental regulation. The Institute is located in China, a choice of site that will make these different and sometimes difficult relationships more visible and amenable to study than they might be elsewhere. Mr. McLellan will observe the Institute's work and carry out extensive interviews with the Institute's staff. He will follow a selection of long-term projects, participating in research meetings, field surveys, and other scientific activities. In order to understand how farmers view the scientists, he also will devote 3 months to living in one of the indigenous communities.

This kind of intensive research at the local-level is characteristic of ethnographic research. It allows the researcher to understand not only what people do but also the categories they have for their work and each other, which affect their activities in ways that are not visible in more superficial survey research. There has been an increasing call for scientists to do a better job of communicating their research to the public and make it useful to policy makers. This project will look closely at what happens when they try to do exactly that. Findings should be helpful to policy makers charged with environmental protection; to scientists who study environmental impacts; and to people who must deal with both.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This ethnographic project sought to investigate the work of a group of agricultural and ecological scientists at the China office of an international research for development organization, the Agricultural Ecology Institute. As I arrived to conduct participant observation at the Agricultural Ecology Institute in 2014, I found this group of scientists under increasing pressure to turn its high-quality research into ‘development impacts’. This reflects a broader trend wherein scientists across the world are expected to show evidence for the real-world impact of their work. Amongst these practices is something called ‘outcomes thinking’. Outcomes thinking demands that scientists plan activities that maximize their ability to change the knowledge, attitudes or skills of relevant stakeholders (for example, policy-makers, and farmers). Outcomes thinking, moreover, is often connected to a demand that scientists produce evidence that planned-for impacts have in fact materialized. Here, ‘monitoring and evaluation’ (M&E) frameworks are deployed to develop measurable numeric indicators of success.

Existing research has criticized M&E and audit practices like those I observed at the Agricultural Ecology Institute for providing a crude picture of reality. This existing research highlights that the complexities of a scientific research project or of a development initiative cannot be captured by numerical indicators. While these are important insights, my research suggests that scientists’ frustrations lie not in M&E’s inability to provide a fulfilling representation of their work, but rather in the temporal framework M&E imposes. So, for example, a donor’s M&E framework would often require scientists to generate goals at the beginning of a project and commit to subsequently using these goals as the basis for a decisive retrospective evaluation of project success or failure. This temporality sits in contrast to conventional scientific practice wherein goals adopted at the beginning of a project are merely provisional, and subject to ongoing revision as a project unfolds. Here, what frustrated my research subjects was how M&E frames time in a manner that prevents them from evolving and adapting a project’s goals as the project evolves.

A second discrepancy between scientific practice and M&E that I observed at the Agricultural Ecology Institute relates to the kind of power or agency that outcomes thinking and M&E asks scientists to claim. Outcomes thinking and M&E often proceed according to the logic that the greater the influence or agency a scientist exerts over his or her audience the better. My ethnographic research, however, suggests that while scientific practice does involve impositions of scientitsts' constructions of the world, scientific practice also demands that scientists adopt a significant degree of openness to how their ideas are subsequently developed, refuted, or applied. Here, conventional scientific practice encourages scientists to cede the future life of their research to others. Rather than merely maximize their agency, as outcomes thinking might demand, scientists also seek to cede agency to others.

Highlighting these questions of time and agency is not merely a case of better appreciating how scientists understand M&E, audit and outcomes thinking. This project develops its research subject’s preoccupation with temporality and agency so as to suggest new ways for interrogating M&E and audit. So, for example, if outcomes thinking and M&E’s stated aims are to increase the social relevance of science and the potential for public engagement in sciences, we should ask if the frameworks of time and agency M&E imposes are truly conducive to such aims. Most commentators agree that public engagement in the sciences demands that scientists are responsive, humble, and flexible. Such traits, however, are not encouraged by temporal frameworks that imply predetermined goals, nor by asking scientists to maximize their agency. Indeed, this research project suggests that a better starting point for more publicly engaged science might be found in the orientations to time and agency found in those aspects of conventional science that already emphasize flexibility, and ceding agency.

As data analysis and writing up for this project continue, a central challenge will be to craft a response to potentially debilitating M&E and audit frameworks, while at the same time engaging the pressing challenge of how we as scientists engage our publics in a meaningful manner.
